title: Much better than the similarly priced GE unit this replaced.
text:
The GE range hood we had in our kitchen wasn't providing sufficient suction causing fire alarms to activate when cooking over high heat. And the stainless steel case of the GE hood was thin and had very sharp corners. It was also completely open under the hood (literally!) except for the small filter which was attached in an unsecured manner under the 7" fan in the middle. After less than 2 years of use, the GE fan started making clicking sounds, so it was time to replace.

After doing some online research, we decided to go with the Broan model as it had a higher CFM rating and much better reviews overall. Order from Amazon was delivered promptly in secure but easy to open packaging. This range hood several exhaust configuration options, including the 7" vertical ducting option needed for our installation. Even though the instructions are generally easy to follow. The first step is to break a few spot weld connections using a mallet and a screwdriver to remove metal parts not needed. I was able to install this unit mostly by myself. One neat trick is to put the unit on a piece of cardboard that is 30" wide and drill holes on the cardboard to mark the mounting screw locations. They you can tape the cardboard template under the counter where the hood will be placed and drill the pilot holes in the exact locations they are supposed to go. Once you drive the mounting screws (leaving about 1/4" between the screw head and the counter), you can then slide the hood into place and secure it by tightening the mounting screws.

The quality of the Broan stainless steel enclosure is much better than the GE unit it replaced. It also looks elegant with rounded edges and corners and need control buttons. The entire bottom of the unit is covered with two large mesh filters, which aesthetically looks better but also helps with suction as it provides a much larger filter surface for air to flow through.

Broan unit has a much larger fan than the GE unit it replaced. While it provides much better suction, it is also much quieter. It has three speeds and at the slowest speed, you hardly hear the fan running.

Overall, I we are very happy with this product.

title: it kind of work
text: first, my model WTW6300SB0 is listed as compatible. second, no instructions. OK, so no big deal right... there are lots of videos out there on using this tool, however the seat for the top bearing was too large and did not fit into the center of the bearing as it should. I thought well maybe that is how this one is supposed to be so I do everything else and it start putting the bearing in crooked. bad bad bad, so I carefully tap the bearing out of the tub as to not damage either. so I get the bearing back out and go back to the drawing board. I can flip the top bearing seat over to press the bearing in. Awesome... well almost, now with the bearing holder flipped over the bar that hit the tub to hold it all in place doesn't reach... so I change some things around and put it below the nut... not really the way it should be but it worked, except then nothing held the spacer tube in the proper place so the drive shaft could not slide through. So, I very carefully tap the bottom bearing a little so I cane move the spacer tube enough to get the shaft through and just used the nut on the shaft to finish seating the bottom bearing. all in all this tool did help me fix my washer, but because it did not function the way it was meant too it did add considerable time to the already daunting repair. hopefully you will have better luck if you buy this one but if I could do it over I would have spent more money to get a better tool, even if it is just a one time use.

title: A life changer!
text:
I can't believe I lived so long without this marvel! I'm happy to sacrifice my limited counter space to make room for this machine (plus you can put stuff on top of it if you so desire).

It accepts regular caps or powder. I am not using the rinsing/drying agent (whatever that thing is) and it works well for me.

The images where they load the dishwasher are extremely optimistic, there's no way you can put all this dishware in there, and you probably shouldn't anyway. My 12" plates fit just fine, but they steal a space on the other side.

This machine is very silent, except for the few times where it flushes water, but really, it's not disturbing at all. The adapter fits perfectly on my faucet and it's easy to connect and disconnect. I just run water until it gets hot, then plug it in, turn on the dishwasher and sometime later, when it beeps 8 times, turn off the faucet, press the red button to relieve the water pressure, disconnect the water, open the door ajar, come back later when it's all dry and cold and voilà!
Don't handle the content after it's done, it's much too hot and might break, that's valid for all dishwashers...

You do want to get rid of large chunks of food by rinsing your plates first, to not risk clogging up the filter.

I REALLY LOVE my dishwasher. The sight of an empty sink is almost as beautiful as the Sixtine Chapel.

title: ... a year and I have to say I am amazed with it
text: I've had this product now for almost a year and I have to say I am amazed with it. It cleans my clothes better than anything. I use an oxy laundry detergent but just a dab because you don't want anything too sudsy. I usually use cold to temperate water unless it's socks and undies then I let them wash, sit for 5 mins and wash again. Sparkling white. The washing cycle agitates wonderfully and the spin cycle almost completely dries the clothes. They're barely damp. I turn on my fan and they are dry in a half an hour. I have to put the machine up on a small table that's about the same height as my bathtub because there's no pump to get the water out of the machine, it drains via gravity. I thought about buying a small pool pump but for now it's fine. I've saved 30 dollars a week not going to the laundromat anymore and it's convenient and easy to use. I let it dry after I'm done (keeping the lids open) and I spray it with lysol because I don't want mold to grow on it. Also, keep the lint filter clean after every wash before you rinse so you don't get the fuzz on the clothes in the rinse cycle.  I use my long hose hand held shower head to fill it but it has leads for a small hose. My sink would work but it doesn't come apart to attach a hose. I've never had a leak with this item and I did buy a warranty just in case. But so far all is great!!!!! I've recommended this to other people as well.

text:
Update 12/14/20
Still nothing from the seller to help with this issue . They don't read correspondence or understand it . They reply with standard talking points . I will be requesting a claim under A to Z warranty from Amazon. Avoid Interstate Sales at all costs .

As a buyer, my concerns were on the delivery process. One little guy in a big truck left it on a pallet after he got as far as his strength would allow him to push ! They are in the process of replacing the door . I'll update if they don't make good on the repair .
Update : 11/13/20 . The seller has been a nightmare to deal with . I get more apologies then action . The four that came in damaged is not covered to be replaced because the seller never submitted the paid receipt to Samsung . I've spent literally hours trying to fix this mess they made . title: A Better System than Past Efforts
text:
I'm rating four stars because I've replaced other parts several times. I'm not sure on the longevity so ...4 stars for now .

Used this kit as Whirlpool and Kitchenaid parts are interchangeable. I have left scathing comments on how bad the quality of the rack slider wheels and adjustments are on a supposed top of the line product by Kitchenaid. This kit I do have to say is much better quality and out of the box appears to be much better than the other replacement parts I've purchased for my machine KUDS30FX SS1 . I pulled my model number , searched Kitchaid's site and got the part numbers I needed and put them in search on Amazon . It crossed referenced this kit from Whirlpool. I ordered the kit for the top rack . The directions are ok , but I watched the YouTube video posted on the installation and that had great tips. Here is my tip . The kit comes with this one black plastic screw, it's not clear as to its use , or it wasn't to me. This is the adapter you'll need to use your Phillips head screw driver to finish driving in the four screws that secure the wheels to stainless steel slide. Your Phillips screw driver will not fit the screws provided. Insert that one screw into the screw heads provided and then you can drive the screws down all the way . Silly as to why they used this method but ...
The YouTube is also good to watch for tips on how to remove the old system . I highly recommend a viewing . You can stop and back up as you need . Once I watched it was a ten minute job to install the new kit. I didn't attach a link but it's easy to find and there may be others to view as well.

The new kit has a steel slide and is very sturdy. The wheels are still plastic but overall it appears to be better. This will be about the fourth time I've rebuilt my rack or repaired issues . Kitchenaid really dropped the ball on this and they made it worse by the price they charged for the fix. At least this kit was somewhat reasonable compared to past expenses incurred to fix the corners they cut during manufacturing .

title: Total Price Rip Off. No Offense to Amazon - Shame on Whirpool and Kitchen Aid
text: Low review is for the cost. They came in on time and fit, easy to install and if your rack droops you need these. I have replaced these several times on my Kitchen Aid Dishwasher. The price on these cheaply made , plastic, injected molded clips is on par with what the U.S. government pays for toliet seats and hammers. I have a KUD 30 FX 3 S1 Kitchen Aid model with top adjustable rack. These clips break constantly and the rack takes four (4) that's about $80.00 for these cheap plastic clips. If you don't replace the rack droops and doesn't meet up with the water port for the rack leaving the top dishes dirty . There are also the adjustable thumb latches that need to be repacked frequently too . Bad quality . Shame on Whirpool and Kitchen Aid. They have to know about this issue but will not address it and make it right. Instead, they expoilit it by overcharging for parts.

title: Can't beat this ice maker
text:
I bought this unit mainly BECAUSE it accepts ionic distilled water to make ice with, not many other units will. That alone is worth the extra money this unit costs.

It is extremely difficult to find the benefits of drinking distilled water not to mention the benefits of cooking with it, but one thing you should know is, distilled truly does make a slower melting, harder, superior tasting clear ice.

I make my coffee, tea, and other drinks with distilled water. It never made sense to me, to add ice made with tap water to any of them. That is all my fridges ice maker could make so I never hooked it up. I had to always make and keep filled, my own trays. It seemed I was the only one ever filling the trays as they were used. I frequently found only one cube left for my drinks on the hottest of days which required buying bags of tap water ice, yuck! This unit cures ALL of those issues!

This unit does needYuck! manufacture/DIY improvement to stop the water filling the ice trays from splashing into the finished ice in the bin. It eventually melts and/or chunks the ice together. This is no problem if using it right away but putting it in the freezer could make for sloppy looking ice you have to break up, I would not want to serve company.

Either in these reviews for this unit or another unit (I can't remember) somebody came up with a DIY make shift flap to help protect the ice from being splashed. I haven't tried it yet, but definately will. Maybe Google it to find it.

The noise level is very doable, I have nothing to compare it with really, other than it's equal to the small bullet I keep next to it. I can make ice cold smoothies anytime of the night or day and am enjoying that.

I bought the extra insurance this seller offers because I studied up on all ice machines and they can all have issues, regardless of cost. I have read this sellers customer service (if ever needed) is EXCEPTIONAL, but still recommend the extra insurance. Insurance just doesn't cost that much. So far wet ice is my only issue.

Rather than wasting more hours than I already had, searching for ice machines that would use distilled water, offered extra insurance along with having awesome customer service, for half of the price of this unit..... I gladly paid a little more to get it all with this unit and would do it again!!

text:
These knobs are for a gas stove. They do not work for an electric stove because there are no knobs on an electric stove.

If you have a gas stove these are good quality knob protectors. They work really well--almost too well. I can't get the stove knob to work without removing them, and they are hard to remove. It reminds me of my intense struggles with childproof caps on medication. I can never get those lids off without help either.

But at least you know the child can't hurt herself.

title: Great piece of equipment
text:
I live in a very humid state and mold growth is always a concern. I own three or four inexpensive hygrometers I purchased here on Amazon, and this one leaves them all behind in accuracy. It is a great adjunct to the hygrometers which are built into most dehumidifiers.

The device itself is a bright, attractive red, and the control buttons are black with easy-to-read, white labels on them. It fits comfortably in my hand. It has push-button function, and you simply point the probe where you want a reading of the temperature and humidity. I carry it with me from room to room in my house.

In order to use it, all you have to do is turn it on. If you forget to turn it off, it will turn itself off after a few minutes as a battery-saving feature. The LCD screen display has large numbers which are easy to read.

This device comes in a good quality, black, vinyl carrying case, which has a Velcro closure on the flap and a loop on the back for running a belt through it to wear it around your waist.

All in all, this is an excellent product.

title: Vinegar works just as well
text: This product descales the kettle of a Waterwise distiller. It works fine, but it isn't worth buying because plain, inexpensive, white vinegar works just as well. I try not to let too much scale build up in the kettle, but even when I manage to go too long without descaling, I simply pour in undiluted vinegar, let it set overnight and voila! No more scale. When I use this product, it simply doesn't work nearly as well as the vinegar, so I have stopped using it.

text:
This gasket is for LGs with a drain in the door - check for 3 holes at the 6 o'clock position.

title: Love it!
text: This little freezer came quickly and cooled down in about 2 hours. We were looking for a small freezer to supplement the crowded one on our refrigerator. Often when I saw a good sale I could not stock up because the space was limited. At first I planned on getting a 3 cf freezer, but that seemed too small. I'm so glad I found this one. It's just the right size and stores an amazing amount of food. The only complaint I have it that the front has several small dents that show up when the light hits it just right. It actually looks more like the way the “stainless steel” skin is attached. But that is a small trade off for such great space and efficient freezing. So glad I purchased this.

title: Fast cooking but lots to learn.
text:
I was so excited to receive this product. I had been dreaming of an induction range for years and when we updated our kitchen I thought the time was right. It was a little slow in arriving, but that was just a lesson in patience for me. Two days after it arrived we had modified the cabinet space for it so it would fit and I started cooking on it. I was blown away. So fast. Water started to boil in a fairly large pot in less than a minute and was at full boil in three minutes. I love how easy the cooktop is to clean. Matching the pans to the correct diameter cooking area is easy because you have four different sizes to choose from.

The convection oven takes a little getting used to. The waves of heat coming out of the door when I opened it were surprising. And it took forever for it to cool down. I checked and rechecked the controls because it felt like the oven was still on. When I used the oven as a conventional oven I didn't have that problem. Also, a cookie sheet actually blew over the edge of the oven rack when I opened the door using convection. I will probably use the oven in the conventional mode more. It heats up much more quickly than the convection mode too.

I say I will probably use that feature because I don't know what will happen after the service technician gets here next week. I read so many reviews on this range and most were good. There will always be some bad reviews, but I wish I had paid more attention and definitely wish I had purchased it locally so I could return it. Just eight days after it arrived the cooktop failed, in the middle of cooking breakfast. The lights came on and blinked and then shut off. Later the same day it was working fine. Still later the problem had returned. Eight days! And during that time we were out of town for three days so it didn't get used at all while we traveled. So really this very expensive induction range lasted all of 5 days and very few meals. I could not be more disappointed. GE will be sending a service technician out next week, but in the meantime, we have no way to cook. Thank heaven that we have a microwave and a toaster oven that can handle most jobs. I would not recommend this range to anyone. Take the bad reviews to heart and stay away!

UPDATE: While the GE service man was here we discovered that the problem wasn't in the range, but in the plan placement. By moving a pan less than a quarter of an inch it caused the burner to "catch" or "lose" the pan. You need to be VERY aware of pan size and placement on the top of the range. This can result in not being able to use all the burners if you don't have exactly the right size pan to fit. Yesterday I had to use a much bigger pan than I needed because the smallest burner was already taken and the next size burner would not recognize a small pan. This is explained in the owner's manual, but I didn't realize how precise the size of each pan on each burner has to be. I will probably need to buy a few more pots and pans to accommodate the various size burners.

title: Frigidaire 5304461262 Dryer Maintenance Kit from Broan
text: I ordered and used this Frigidaire 5304461262 Dryer Maintenance Kit to change out the back bearing knob and seat felt pads and belt on my dryer, due to a noise it had developed.  I really feel about anyone could do this repair, if you would go to YouTube and watch a couple of maintenance videos on the subject as this is about a 2 or 3 on a scale of 10 for difficulty to perform successfully.  It takes about an hour to two hours to complete, based on your abilities, tools you have and if you can move the dryer out of a small laundry room, like I did, into a larger area to get at everything.  Parts go in easily and the felt removal on the front of the dryer section that fits into the front of the drum, being the most time consuming.  I like it well enough, the quiet dryer a lot !

title: Frigidaire 5303937182 Upper Seal by Broan
text: This Frigidaire 5303937182 Upper Seal installed easily after removing the old seal, which was tedious to get all of the felt off the adhesive left on the drum.  I have done quite a bit of maintenance on appliances and after adequate removal the gluing of the new seal came easy and the adhesive dried quickly on the upper and lower full felt seal and is working well in the newly repaired drum bearing on the back, seals and belt.  Can't complain and will return and up the rating if I feel it is warranted.

I like that aspect, but the adhesive is not for liking the container, rather how it holds up in use and that will be determined by it either holding the dryer glide for the tub I needed to replace. title: Helping with an old fridge
text: We're in a rental with an old fridge. The seals are warped, and the doors don't always close reliably. Despite the pulls in the way, this lock appears to be helping. It took me just a moment to figure out. I wedged the door tightly shut and attached the lock, then left it to set for 24 hours. The seal looks straighter, the door closes tighter, and the lock is holding well so far. At least now we know the door is shut as tight as possible, and I think it has to be helping with any cold air loss. It's no extra trouble to open and close the door. We just put a sticky note up in the beginning to remind us to push the buttons instead of just yanking on the door. I'm very glad we came across these. Well worth $9.99 as I think it's saving energy and preserving the life of the appliance.

title: Leak stopped like a magic!
text:
The parts is made by Supco and it's semi-translucent unlike the one in the photo(and the original parts) but it works just as it was promised.
Replacing the pump was easy. The hard part of the repair was replacing the washer panel(front and side panels all in one piece), specially if you don't know how to remove and put it back. It's pretty tricky.
If you don't know it, here's how.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OlAFQnkapLM
The old pump didn't have any crack so the water probably was leaking from the seal. It's a 25 yr old washer, so it's about time something start failing. If you start seeing a leak under the washer, replacing the pump should be the first thing you should try. In my case, it was very hard to tell where the leak coming from just by looking at it.
This was my first time repairing the washer and I was quite nervous before I opened up the machine, so I checked around youtube and watched as many videos as I could find. It helped me build up my confidence.
As all repair jobs specially the ones involving water, it's quite messy but the effort is worth it.
The delivery was very fast, it took less than a week from the date of order and two days before the estimated delivery.

title: Excellent for tea, not for coffee
text:
It works really good for loose tea. It looks strange to see yellow liquid(green tea) with no small leaves at the bottom like I was so used to see but all I see is just a hint of powder in the cup.
I also tried coffee. I wasn't so impressed by this. There's a lot of coffee bean silt at the bottom and foamy residue at the top. I'll stick with paper filter for now even though I'm not thrilled by the idea of throwing away disposable paper each time. I thought about deducting one star from this but since I didn't buy it for the coffee, I left it.
Over all, it's an excellent product, design, material and built-wise. I brewed tea and coffee then tea again one after another but smell of coffee didn't seem to stay on it. Between each time, all I had to do was rinse it with water, no soap.

Now the detailed dimension I wanted to know before I bought it but I couldn't find.
Height: 75mm

Height to the underside of the top rim(this decides if the basket sits on the bottom of the cup or the top of the cup): 73mm

Foot print: 47mm in diameter, quickly tapered(about 45 degree angle) to 52mm(bottom of the mesh cylinder).

Top of the mesh cylinder: 57mm in diameter

Above the mesh cylinder but underside of the rim(this decides the minimum diameter of the cup when the basket sits on top of the cup): 62mm in diameter.
This means, if you have a cup little smaller than 62mm inside diameter at the top, the basket may not go down all the way but maybe partly goes in the cup. Under 57mm, you probably won't get a good result.

Far end of the handle to the opposite: 98mm
Length of each handle: 18mm
This means, if you have a cup between 62mm and 80mm in diameter at the top, the basket sits on the top without positioning. Between 80mm and 98mm, you'll need careful positioning of the basket or the basket will fall in the cup. Above 98mm, it'll always fall, unless the basket sits on the bottom of the cup.

*update* (2-20-11)
Sample photos have been posted for visual comparison. I hope it'll help your decision making better.

title: Stopped working properly after 2 uses - Read the manual before you purchase!
text:
Updated Review: I noticed on the first use that that top "spinning" thing where water comes out would spin the stop, then spin and stop spinning. I thought maybe this was how it worked. But then on the second use, the top spinner was spinning fine. Well, this morning I put my new corelle dishes in for a quick clean and the top spinner didn't spin at all, and water was dripping from the bottom of the door. Sadly, after speaking with customer service my only option is to return the unit for a refund. Not an easy task because i'm disabled so my son will have to help me pack up the unit for UPS to pick it up.

Original Review: So, I'm not thrilled with the purchase, but I'm not upset either. I should have read the manual before I purchased it. It takes 2 hours for a normal wash which includes the dry function - OMG seriously??? This is a fraction of the size of a normal dishwasher and you expect me to run it for 2 hours? I opted for the rapid wash which took 40 minutes - guess what, no dry function with this option. Ok, I let my hand washed dishes air dry no biggie. Well, even 4 hours after the wash was done and the door was left open the dishes were still wet. Anyway, If you have larger dishes this will not hold 30 items. I was able to fit 1 large dish, 1 cereal bowl, 4 coffee mugs, one small drinking glass. I also used the cutlery tray and was able to get 4 spoons and 3 forks on the rack. Upside is dishes all came out clean. I cut an eco friendly dishwasher tablet in half. I think in the future I'll just use a few drops of Dawn as others have commented that they use. I am considering doing a return because I found another unit that has better cycle options and a separate dry option. Not sure what I'm going to do.

text: After five years seeing code E02 coming up, but washer still works fine.  Cleaned out drain pump compartment, easy access, no tools required, just a rag and old toothbrush.  Pros: highly efficient, good clean, far fewer problems with the septic system since going to a front loader (family of 7, lots of water use.)  Cons: 1) Very low, need to raise it up.  Instead of $200 "Pedestal" I bought four cinder blocks and used a spare (very thick) peice of plywood with moulding around the edges to prevent slippage - it does shift slightly over time.  2) need to prop the door open with a rag to keep the gasket dry so it doesn't grow mold.  Helps to wipe door gasket out occasionally to prevent mold and grime buildup, not a big deal.  Cycle time can be unpredictable, but supposedly due to sensors and machine intelligence.  Normal cycle time starts out at 1:00, gets down to :50, then changes to 1:10.  Overall been a good machine. Switched from decades of loyalty to Sears/Whirlpool after getting really screwed by Sears.  Bought at Lowes, they delivered, installed, and took away the junk from Sears at no extra cost.  The 300 doesn't have the frills of more expensive machines, but has all the features you need to get your clothes clean.  "Kids Clean" cycle uses 150 degree water for tough jobs and sanitation.  The 300 series doesn't have 170 degree option if you really like your clothes cooked. If you like more bells and whistles, I understand another $500 could keep you happy.  If not, save the bucks and keep it simple.

title: A little extra effort
text: Cleaning requires extra effort, it makes these a bit less convenient than the standard pods. But with these you can use any coffee, even fresh ground stuff. After use I tend to set them aside for a day or two to dry, it makes the coffee or tea a bit easier to dumb out, and rinse the rest out. A small amount of effort yields a great benefit to reducing the pod waste. The spent coffee is easy to collect for the garden this way too.

title: DIY Euphoria
text:
Dryer was making a super loud knocking sound. Found out on you tube that the wheels needed to be replaced.

Dryer appliance repair technician quoted some astronomical price to replace the wheels in our dryer.

Watched the videos on you tube and proceed on our own with these wheels. FYI these wheels do not come with the piece/shaft that goes thru the center. So not sure why it is referred to as an "assembly."

However, for the rear wheels which is 2 of the four it is actually easier if one does not try to install new shafts and simply replaces the wheel on the existing shaft.

However, a word to the wise. This is not rocket science but it is "screw" science. There were a boat load of screws. So we used zip loc bags to collect each set of screws and labeled each bag to remind us what screws went where.

In hindsight if we ever have to do it again we would also add a # to each bag. So the first set of screws would go in a zip loc bag labeled #1 with a written description plus take a corresponding picture with a smartphone in case by the time we got to bag #17 the description say for bag #3 was meaningless because of the obvious learning curve. Took 2 people, the newbie diy home tech and the screw tech assistant the better part of 2 days to complete the repair.

But when we were done, the dryer worked beautifully like new, very quite.

We only had 1 screw leftover when we were done. But hey! Saved a hefty cache of cash :-) And garnered some serious diy euphoria!

Ready to build a city now!

title: Really Annoying Door Alarm CANT TURN OFF

On this model there is no way to disarm the door alarm and as far as LG is concerned it is the consumer's responsibility to bear the cost to hire an appliance technician to turn this off. So when loading groceries to cooking your expected to only leave the door open for a few seconds.

Update: This frig has an issue with the flow of air from the freezer to the fridge. You can only fill the freezer about 2/3 or the refrigerator will stop cooling and everything will go bad.

Also the computer board on this frig is extremely expensive and problematic, we found out the hard way and after we had no recourse through seller and manufacturer. LG does not stand behind their products.

title: I'm up and down about this ice maker
text:
When I first used it I noticed that the ice cubes were little hollow bullets with thin walls that melted as soon as they hit the basket. But as the ice maker kept working, the cubes got sturdier and I thought "yeah, this is great!" I made enough to fill my ice tray, not realizing that the bullets would freeze together since they come out of the maker with a lot of surface dampness. No matter, I can break up the clumps pretty easily. Unfortunately, the bullets melt very fast in any liquid, which means that unless you down your beverage quickly, you're going to end up with a cool, watered down drink.

Bottom line for me: Convenient way to make extra ice, but nothing to rely on for a permanent solution.

title: My thinking on a fridge filter for lead:
text:
The main difference between this filter and the OEM and more expensive replacements is that this does not filter out heavy metals like lead. My thinking is that if there is lead in my water supply then that is a much bigger problem than a fridge filter can fix! I only use the fridge water for drinking water, and if I am using a small glass. If I am taking a big cup outside, drinking from my bathroom cup after brushing my teeth, or when I am cooking I use tap water, so if there was lead in my water supply this would hardly keep my family safe.

We have very high quality public water here in Phoenix, they test and report often. So unless I want to use water from the fridge filter for everything then a lead filter is, in my opinion, not neccessary.

My $0.02 and probably just about worth each penny!

title: So pleased I'm buying another one.
text:
I may never buy tea bags again. Loose leaf allows me to make my own blends according to my mood, and make them as strong or as weak as I want. That said, how do I like this particular infuser? I'm very happy with it. It is well made, and after more than a year of very frequent use It's still in great shape and I have yet to be disappointed in it. I got the large size, which I recommend to everyone. I've also recently begun making my own "garden tea" from flowers and herbs in my own yard. (Don't do this without first researching the safety of each plant and plant part! Some food plants have poisonous leaves, for example.)

Advantages to making tea with an infuser:
* Infusing tea with an infuser is considerably less expensive than making similar quality tea from tea bags, and makes a better product because of superior flow.
* Blend tea yourself in your preferred varieties and proportions.
* Even make homemade herbal tea.

Pros:
* The large size allows flow space.
* The large infuser fits in normal or large coffee mugs, or in a normal sized tea pot. The rim keeps it from falling in. Very versatile.
* Very easy to clean. If cleaned right away, it rinses clean.
* No metal parts to bend. It retains its shape well.
* No metal parts also means you won't burn your hands on it.
* The lid is an extra bonus; you can use it for putting the infuser on after you're finished steeping.

Cons:
* It's a little tricky to wash if you let the tea leaves dry in it too long.

Bottom line: this is a phenomenal price for a product that holds up well and makes the best tea I've ever made.

title: Worked perfectly - plus a tip...
text:
My Frigidaire Galaxy side-by-side stopped cooling in both sides and so I hit up youtube to figure out that it may be the evaporator fan motor.

The price is fantastic and within 20 minutes I had it replaced and cooling again. So many videos showed that you have to take out the whole ice maker assembly, a chore I wasn't relishing. And then I found an old guy showing that you don't have to remove the complete back panel since it's flexible and you can leave the ice maker in place! (Pull out the ice maker drawer, however.) He used a tie wrap (I used a piece of yarn - cause that's what I had nearby and I'm just an 'old' lady, lol) and after you take out the bottom most 5 screws you flex the panel up and tie it through the screw hole to the ice maker bracket to get it out of your way.

I turned off my circuit at the breaker box so I didn't even have to pull out the fridge from the wall to unplug it. Take ice make drawer out, remove the shelves and bottom basket, take 5 screws out and tie panel up to the ice maker bracket, remove motor, remove fan from old and put on new, put back in place, screw the back panel down, replace shelves and you're done. :) (Oh, and turn the breaker back on.)

title: Well Engineered & Good Output
text:
It took a bit of trial and error, but, I got the machine working well. Instructions could have been a lot clearer.
Water is poured into a reservoir that holds about 1 1/2 liters. The machine produces a "rack" of ice about every 15 minutes. Four cycles will fill the catch box holding the ice. This needs to be emptied after 20 minutes or so since the ice will begin to melt as if it were in a refrigerator. The melt drains off and recycles through the machine so it is not a problem if one doesn't mind smaller ice cubes; they are small to begin with.

The machine works by water flowing from a horizontal tube with many very small holes that allow water to flow over the ice-making rack. It is obvious that the water put into the reservoir must be scrupulously clean. I currently use only filtered water. I think this is essential to prevent a breakdown.

The size of the cubes does vary and can be adjusted. Some people put the fresh ice into bags before putting the ice in a freezer. This is helpful since the fresh ice will "clot" and need to be separated somewhat. I use a wood mallet for the purpose. If the ice is placed into a plastic bag just dropping it on a counter should work to separate the ice.

The making of ice is quite noisy. If I am in the same room as the machine, it sounds like a truck going by.

I am impressed so far. Fridgedaire put a lot of thought into the machine. Cheaper versions of ice-makers have a high rate of negative reviews while Fridigaire has good reviews overall. You will pay for that— It's worth it.

title: Not An Exact Fit But...
text:
These filters are not smooth but ridged/textured and aren't all cut precisely round so they are either a little too big for the Aeropress filter holder or slightly misaligned, but they work OK (you will get a little more fine grit in the bottom of your cup).

However, for the price, they are adequate. There's no reason for OEM Aeropress filters to cost so much for disposable filters and metal screens don't remove the chlorogenic acid that causes higher blood pressure so it's paper for the best results. Since you get so many, you really do save quite a bit more money per cup.

They work very well and are easy to clean. Very highly recommended product, definitely worth purchasing.

title: Best tea infuser/filter on the market
text: Using this product, it's easy to see why it is the top rated filter/infuser by the NYT staff. The mesh is so fine that even very powdery teas like Kusmi and others with ground spices in the blend are no problem. I find no sediment in my teapot when using this Finum basket. Despite the fine mesh, water flows through it easily and steeping performance is quite good. It's easy to hand clean and holds up in the dishwasher as well. The product is so well made and so superior to the more common perforated stainless products, there's really not much more to say. It's a huge upgrade over the infusers most teapots, even good ones, come with. Buy it, you'll be glad you did.

The downsize is that this is a tad messy. After making a cup of coffee you will want to clean it, and loading 2 tablespoons of coffee at a time can be tedious at times.

Also the instructions suggest using coarser ground coffee. I used finer ground coffee and found the results were more suited to my taste. So I would definitely suggest this more for someone who has control over how finely their coffee is ground.

title: Work great on a Whirlpool range
text:
The coil burner elements on our Whirlpool range (model WFC150MLAW, FYI) were beginning to misbehave a bit (like the larger ones were going to red hot and staying there sometimes no matter where you set the control knob). I figured it was time to replace them. Original equipment replacements were pricey. There was a slight difference from the originals in design. These replacements had an extra turn in the coils. But I checked the measurements and took a chance they'd work.

And they DO work. They fit and look better than the original coils. The extra turn in the coils seems to make them a little slower to get to red hot, but they're really efficient at heating and are no slower to get pots and pans to cooking temperature than the original coils.

So yeah they work and they look great. Just measure to make sure they'll fit and check that the connectors are the right type for your range.

title: Durable porcelain enamel finish
text:
I was using the shiny chrome drip pans but I had to replace them more than once because they get stained and rust. One on the last set rusted completely through. So I decided to pay a little more and go with these.

Since they're porcelain enamel coated, they're probably a lot more rust resistant. Since they're black, they don't show stains. And they fit very well. The burners sit nice and level on them.

title: Cheaper sets don't work as well
text:
I tried to save a few bucks by buying a cheaper set of these suspension rods. They worked okay for a short while but just couldn't stabilize large loads in the washer. The slamming resumed.

I watched a few online videos and found (according to a couple of videos I found online, so take it with a grain of salt) that it's not the springs that are the key to how these rods work. It's the cap on top of the spring. The cap has a collar that fits rather tightly on the rod and slides up and down, but with some resistance. Apparently that resistance is what provides the damping and stops the slamming. When that collar loosens over time and the cap slides too easily, the slamming starts.

I saw some innovative fixes. One was to use construction adhesive around the collar to increase the friction. Another was to put a small cable tie around the collar and cinch it tightly enough to increase it.

Or you could just buy this set of replacement rods. This set works. Washer is slamming no more. Several videos are available online that show how to install them.

title: These worked to stop the slamming
text:
We've had a Roper RTW4640YQ1 quite a long time. I keep fixing it instead of buying a new one. I think I've replaced the shift actuator three or four times, the main control board once, the transmission once (and incidentally the washer seemed to work better than it did new after I replaced it), and the main motor capacitor once.

When the drum started slamming around on spin cycle, I decided to go ahead and buy a new washer. Since I was familiar with this model and know how to repair it, I ordered one like it. After the order was delayed a couple of times, I decided to cancel and once again fix the old one.

I looked around on the Internet and discovered the suspension rods were the likely problem. After watching a couple of how-to videos, it looked like a pretty easy fix.

I had a delay though because I ordered the wrong rods to start with. The rods that fit our machine are part number W10780048, and are about 23 and 1/2 inches long. I found a listing for part number ERW10780048, and thought that must be a match since all but the first two letters were the same number. Nope. Those rods are about three inches longer and didn't fit. I returned them and ordered these correct size ones.

The only glitch I encountered in installing them was the drum got snagged on the overlapping seam of the metal panel on the back as I was trying to lift one of the rear rods into its position. I didn't realize that was why I had to pull so hard to get it situated. I freed the drum from the seam and things went a lot more smoothly.

Anyway I got them installed and it solved the problem. The machine is spin cycle-ing nicely again without slamming.

[**UPDATE** -- After running several loads I've come to think the springs in these rods aren't quite as strong as the the ones on the original equipment rods. Some slamming does still occur with larger loads. It's still an improvement, but not quite up to "as new" performance.]

[**UPDATE 2** -- I finally gave up and bought a more expensive set of replacement rods. Search for "Whirlpool W10780048 Suspension, 24", white." They work better.]

One more repair I did while I had the machine out: One of the bottom front corners has gotten rusty, so I reinforced it by fastening blocks of pressure treated 2 x 4 on the inside by running screws through the sheet metal from the front and side. It doesn't look great, but it's sturdy.

Oh, by the way, I did order those smaller springs to put at the top, but as other reviewers have said, they're not needed. They don't provide much tension, and on our machine there were only installation holes on three of the corners of the drum assembly. Besides, the washer did not come with them originally, and it worked fine without them for years. I gave them a look-over and decided to not bother with installing them.

So just double-check your part numbers, and you might even want to go ahead and remove one of the rods before ordering so you can measure the length and make sure it matches up to what you're ordering.

title: Perfect for an RV when a laundromat isn't available
text:
I've seen some YouTube reviews on this and similar items. I live in an RV full time without a laundromat near by. So I purchased this to wash my clothes.

The washer is a little noisy but if I shut my bathroom door, I don't hear it as much. When I first got it the back wasn't properly snapped into place but that was easily fixed. The hose provided to fill the washer is useless, I just put my shower head into the tub.

When I use this, I put about a tablespoon to 1.5 tablespoons of liquid laundry detergent for a large load with about half a scoop of oxi clean. I run my machine for 15 mins and then let it sit. I will drain the dirty water and rinse the tub a little bit. Then close the drain and fill with clean water and run for 15 more minutes. Then I will drain again. Pull half if the clothes and spin them for at max 4 mins. After the spin, they are damp but quickly dry.

There are water levels for low, middle, and high water marks on the lint filter but they are hard to see. The lint filter is a nice way to catch loose thread but it doesn't filter all of the water.

I store it behind my entertainment center and it fits really well there. The issue is getting into my bathroom. I have to go up a small set of stairs to the bathroom and it's a little bulky to easily get up there. Because it has legs, I can have it in my shower when it's draining and not have to worry about the motor getting wet.

Overall, it's a nice machine. I can put 2 pairs of jeans and several shirts in a load. I have even fit my entire queen sized sheet set including pillow cases into it.

title: Ehhh....came bent, and the collars aren't the right size
text:
I decided, to make more space in my small laundry room, to stack my two front-loaders. I wanted a clean, professional look for the duct, but it had to be something that could reach at least 30". I went back and forth between this item and [[ASIN:B00009V3TL Dundas Jafine UD48 Space Saver Aluminum Dryer Duct, Extends 28-Inch to 45-Inch]]. I wish I'd bought that one instead.

Firstly, though the box was not damaged, there was a big dent in one half of housing...so someone packed it for shipping knowing it was damaged.

Secondly, the collars are neither tapered or sized to overlap the collar to which you're connecting them, so you're not going to be able to slip them into or over either your standard outlet collar OR a standard expandable duct--unless you plan to use a roll of foil tape to butt the two together and hope for the best. Also, because they are hard collars, you can't use a screw clamp to secure them, even if they DID fit. I ended up cutting one of the collars off completely and used some high-temp hot glue to attach it to [[ASIN:B0028BAAWW Dryer Dock Vent Hose Quick Connect]], and the other I did the tape thing...for now.

Also, even though the picture looks like the duct is slim and sturdy, it's not. Imagine taking a regular thin-tin duct and smooshing it a bit to make it more oval. That's what this is like--and it dents and becomes misshapen very easily.

I'm going to order the other item now--do yourself a favor and avoid this one.

title: Keeps pipe clean, no fire hazard!
text: After hearing of several dryer fires, I figured this would be a good thing to have. I kept adding until i was at the end of the vent, then did a couple of feet, stopped, took 2 rods off, and repeated the process until the brush came back out at the bottom. title: Friendly to the Environment
text:
I've been using a Keurig for 10 years and I LOVED the convenience of the K-Cups, but the waste was a consideration. Also, a consideration - the amounts of ground and bean coffee I would be given as gifts.

I decided to get a Perfect Pod, which is MUCH better than the cups that came with this. And, of course, I invested in filters.

They got more expensive and I had to look into alternatives.

These work, but don't have the "top flap" which causes the top of the plastic cup to get dirty and need cleaning.

Otherwise, these work as an affordable alternative.

title: Not that Great
text:
This kit MIGHT be useful if it were better designed. Unfortunately, this has a few strikes against it.

Reusable Cups – These are like MANY reusable cups I've seen. They can be used with the filter or without. They do filter out the grounds, but only allow for ONE cup at a time use – meaning, if you're brewing more than one – you have to clean it out.

Filters – these do not have a “paper lid” (see the ones for the Perfect Pod system). This causes the grounds to STICK to the top of the cup, much like the grounds sticking to the sides of the provided cup.

When using the filters with the cups – you get less coffee per “cup”. Without the filter? You have a HUGE mess to clean up.

The only thing good was the scoop. I loved the adorable heart at the end.

Honestly, I'd prefer using the Perfect Pod system as it definitely works, even with the Keurig machine I got back in 2011 (yes, over 10+ years ago).

The cups are expensive, but I've been using mine since about that long. The filters? You can find cheaper ones.

While this is a cheaper set by virtue of price, it is “pass it by” kind of thing.

title: Good Idea, Needs Serious Improvement
text:
When I got my Keurig in late 2012, I thought it was the BEST coffee maker I ever bought. But, not only does those K-Cups get expensive, but they're also not too good for the environment.

Don't get me wrong, I'm not a NO PLASTIC EVER kind of person. I'm not a tree hugger. I'm also not “hey let's create a boatload of waste” either. I do what I can, where I can, when I can to reduce my imprint.

As a result, along with my Keurig, I purchased a reusable cup. At that time it was the “PERFECT POD” one, and I also got their filters. And, they were pretty affordable. Sometimes hard to find.

I'm always on the lookout for a GREAT deal. Seeing these, I thought I would try them.

One thing I should've noticed and didn't, and this is 100% on me, they don't have a “lid”. If you want to know what I mean, check out my pictures. The white filters are PERFECT POD, the unbleached ones are this product.

Notice the white filter as a “lid”. This is quite useful when putting the ground in. Without the lid to cover them, they tend to fall out of the reusable cup whether the filter is FULL or not. This can lead to some grounds in the machine, your cup, and makes the top of the filter nasty to clean. The white filter with the lid prevents that entirely.

These are not easy to store or take out of the package. ALL 600 FILTERS are in ONE bag. NO individual bags to take out and store the rest until needed. One has to open the WHOLE BOX, WHOLE BAG, to get one (1) filter. I decided to grab a “group” of filters and store them in another bag.

Do these work? Aside from those issues, yes. There is no difference in the taste of the coffee. Then again I usually chill it then mix with chocolate milk for a mocha.

Whether one wants to buy these depends on whether they want to clean the K-Cup EVERY SINGLE CUP (thankfully I do have two reusable cups), and do they want to open the box and bag for one (1) filter.

Given the filter's design -1 star; packaging -1 star.

While they're still a good value, my next group will either be my old brand or a cheaper brand with the lid. I honestly wouldn't get these again, and I don't recommend them.

title: Poor Design & Function
text:
As someone that likes to use her own coffee, and have been using re-usable filters for years - I thought I would check these out.

The idea, or so I thought, was that you put the coffee in and wouldn't need a filter. After all, the less waste generated is the best. And, I try to limit what I waste - within reason.

Turns out that isn't the case. I cannot make but one cup per filter. That's it. The cup HAS to be washed out EACH TIME IT IS USED, and it is messy to clean with the grounds going all over the sink. I would not recommend emptying this over a trash can unless you want a mess. I was lucky the first time, but didn't chance it again.

And, if I do use a filter - less coffee in the "pod". So, I am back to using the other pod with filters. Thankfully I have a few until an order comes in.

I'll still use these if I get into a bind, but definitely won't get them again. I honestly can't recommend them either.

title: Smaller Coffee Filters
text:
In 2011 I was super excited to have a K-Cup machine to make coffee by the cup rather than a pot as I was (and still am) the only coffee drinker in the household. Also, the k-cup machine took up less space than my coffee maker and was much easier to clean and maintain.

However, I would still end up with ground/bagged coffee as gifts, etc. I had no way to use them. Also, the plastic k-cups were getting to be a problem – storage and varieties among them.

To ease both problems, I looked into a reusable k-cup and found the Perfect Pod system in 2012. The cup was perfect and the filters were easy to use, easy to store, and I could even use my bagged/ground coffees again.

These work about the same way as the bigger coffee filters – you pop it in, fill it to the desired point (for strength), pop it in. When done (and cool) – you pop the plastic cup out and toss the tiny filter. That's a tad bit more environmentally friendly than the disposable ones. If properly maintained the main cup doesn't need to be cleaned.

I've been a Perfect Pod customer since 2012 and still one today, and I'll likely be one into the future. I just wish I could afford the 200 filter pack :)

title: Replacement filters
text:
The java jig is one of my preferred reusable k-cups. I find it to be the easiest to use and clean of all the reusable k-cups I've tried. This is especially true if you don't have a garbage disposal, so you can't just wash all your grounds down the drain. As it uses paper filters, it requires the purchase of these. It's kind of annoying that tiny filters are more expensive than big filters, but I still like my java jig enough to keep using it and keep buying the filters. It's still MUCH cheaper than buying k-cups.

Be aware, this is just the replacement filters, not the java jig itself.

title: A little noisy, and the ice is a bit melty, but it does what it says it will
text:
It runs fairly quickly, making ice inside of five minutes indoors in 80 degree weather (no air conditioning in the room it is in, but no direct sunlight either). It runs reasonably quietly. It will make a brief noise similar to a computer fan running at times. It will make a clunking noise as the ice drops into the basket. It will make a very loud beeping noise when the ice basket is filled or the water supply is empty. I'd rather it simply light a light (it automatically stops anyway) and not be so disruptive. This isn't something you want to leave running overnight anywhere you can hear it (not that it would make sense to do so, since it would just be making the same ice over and over and it would make more sense just to put the basket load in the freezer or start again the next day) and it's a little annoying for a movie night. That's the main reason it's losing a star.

It doesn't keep the ice frozen. That's not its intended function. Instead it makes ice and then drops them in a basket above the water reservoir. As the ice melts the water fills the reservoir, from which it is then pulled to make new ice. You can have your choice of small or large cubes.

It makes the kind of ice that has a hole in the middle, and not very thick walls even when set to large and that this gives the ice a lot of surface area, which means it melts very quickly. I would prefer the ice be a bit more solid, but a friend of mine thinks it's just fine if the ice is a bit "melty" so it's a matter of individual taste.

It comes with a tiny ice scoop that would fill about half of a lowball glass with ice on a single scoop. It's very cute and very convenient.

It has two buttons, one for power, the other for choosing if you want small or large cubes. It's about as easy to operate as a device can be.

Overall, I think it will be a convenient device for entertaining in the summer.

title: great machine!
text:
[[VIDEOID:8833d77b66a356f7d450726db6ee7913]] UPDATE:
Almost a year later and it is still working great. No issues at all!

ORIGINAL REVIEW:
Simple and easy to use. I ran the cleaning cycle and then made ice. My machine seems to average 7 minutes per batch and then pops out 10 "cubes". That is around 85/86 "cubes" per hour. I ended up making ice while I was home. I just baby sat the machine. I could hear the ice drop. I then transferred it to a ziplock bag in our freezer. However, aside from having a distinctive dropping noise, it is really quiet.

I chose this because we do not have an ice maker. I actually haven't had an ice maker in my life for several years. Ice cube trays just never worked for us in terms of space used in our freezer. I am excited, now I can enjoy iced coffee and also ice bath our hard boiled eggs after cooking them. It is the little things in life.

This is pretty space efficient. Not ugly. Works well for its size. Easy to use. I am super happy to have it. No complaints of regrets.

It takes longer than you think to make any sort of volume of ice, but this machine does work. The ice tends to melt quickly, so it's best to put some in a Ziploc bag and put it in the freezer. My main reason for liking these sorts of machines is that you don't get any of the off taste.
The ice that my refrigerator makes has a plastic odor and taste. My only complaint is that this unit is a bit pricey in comparison with similar icemakers.

title: Cleaner Coffee
text:
If you don't use the old fashioned trick of using an egg in the grounds, perked coffee has a lot of 'sludge'.
These filters make the most out of a perked pot.
Cleaner coffee and less mess when getting the spent grounds from the machine.
Filters for percolators are harder and harder to find, so it's nice to find them reasonably priced and delivered.

title: A Great Cuppa
text:
When I was telling a friend about this product, and how well it worked even without using a paper filter, she got so excited and asked if she could bring it to her college dorm in the fall.
Limited space, no buying filters, and a really delicious way to brew coffee makes this perfect for her.

My only concern with this product, is that I strongly suggest hand washing. That is no problem because all you do is gently tap it with your hand to remove most of the grounds, and then Swish and some soapy water for a few seconds. The reason I say this is because I have a similar one and noticed that for some reviewers, the cone separated from the base, although that did not happen with me. After using this model, I don't think that's an issue as it seems to be very secure.
Perhaps I'm being overly cautious by not putting it in the dishwasher, but it's so nice and convenient that it's worth a few extra seconds to clean it.

If you are giving this as a gift, please know that it comes nicely packaged. After my friend got so excited, this would be a terrific part of a coffee gift basket for someone going off to college or getting their first apartment.
It's also a nice option for someone that doesn't drink coffee, but occasionally entertains people who want just a cup or two, because it doesn't take up much storage space and you don't have to worry about those filters.

title: Clean, Fresh Ice (UPDATE)
text:
[[VIDEOID:9bb528d767827637c2d4eba863317730]] If you need ice in a hurry, this machine is for you.

In under 10 minutes, you will have enough ice to fill your glass.
Operation could not be more simple. After un-boxing, let the machine sit for 30 minutes before turning it on. That's very important, because the refrigerant has to stabilize. And if you've had an ice maker before, you might forget the important step.

Anyway, after a quick wash of the machine, all you do is fill it with water, select the size cube you want, and let the machine work its magic.
One thing about this, and any ice machine, is the importance of keeping it super clean. Even restaurant ice machines often have high levels of bacteria. You can avoid that by regularly wiping this machine clean. If you don't use it for a while, make sure that you dry it as well as you can, and leave the lid open in order to air dry even more.

The cubes are bullet shaped and hollow. If you like to crunch ice, use the setting to make small cubes, or should I say, bullets.
Another nice feature about this machine is the long cord. When entertaining, I like to set up a table with beverages. The cord is long enough to go down the table and into the electrical outlet.
As the video shows, it doesn't make a lot of noise, and certainly will not interfere with a party where music is played and people are having fun.
My freezer is generally too full to store ice cubes, and it never fails. Whenever I make hard boiled eggs, they go from hot water to ice water, and of course I don't have any ice cubes. With this, while the eggs are coming to a boil, the machine makes enough ice to chill the eggs when they are done cooking.

UPDATE: I've been using this ice machine everyday for almost a month. In the early evening, I start up the machine. Within 10 minutes, of course, I have enough ice for my glass, but then I keep the machine going and it fills up in a few hours. Now there is enough ice not only for the whole evening, but I unplug the machine and keep it filled with ice. In the morning, the ice is still there.
A bit melted, but there is enough insulation in this machine to keep a full load of ice until morning. For me, and perhaps for you, that is huge because I have no room in my freezer.

As stated in my original review, the following is of the utmost importance. Every few days or so, in between the morning iced coffee and the evening start up, the water is emptied, and I use a very weak (one half teaspoon to a cup of water) vinegar solution and a lint free cloth to wipe the interior clean. Then the lid is left open to air dry. Always empty the water and do this if you don't plan on using it for a few days. You can turn the machine on its side to get every last bit of water out, if you like, but remember that 30 minute rule to let the refrigerant stabilize. It sounds like a lot of maintaining but it isn't.
This machine is wonderful for ice-a-holics like me!
And I admit to being overly cautious.

title: Natural filters in a hard to find size
text:
After a recent purchase of a one cup pot with a small cone for making pour-over coffee, the search began for the elusive #1 filter.
Fortunately the good folks at Melitta have high quality, unbleached super small filters. No sediment left in the cup, but all the flavor finds it's way. Very pleased.

title: I DO Care! Wonderful filters
text:
For many reasons, these filters are an excellent choice.
Am I totally 'green'? Heck no. It's nearly impossible in the world that we currently lived in. And I'm not as Earth wise as I could or should be. I still use bleach in my laundry once in a while.
So...when there is even a tiny step that is a no brainer, count me in.

These filters are that step. Not only better for the planet, but better for your body. And they work nicely. As long as you use the correct grind, they do not clog. Too fine a grind and they clog, as will most filters.
Coffee tastes great, and are the perfect small size.

title: Best for my Honey BUNN
text:
Regular basket filters will work fine in my 8 cup Bunn, and I've used them for a few years as they are much cheaper than Bunn filters.

Or shall I say they USED to be! These 100 pack boxes are now cheaper than 'generics', and fit perfectly in the tall Bunn basket.
Even though they feel thicker than other filters, the flow is perfect.
I have all kinds of coffeemakers, and use them all. Bunn is my favorite drip maker, especially with Bunn filters.

title: LOVE my Phin!
text:
My first phin was the screw-down type, and I absolutely love it, but sometimes you just want one less step. After looking into gravity models, this is the one I chose.
Boy, am I happy! It may not offer as much tweak room, but still makes an incredible Vietnamese coffee, drop by drop.
My Vietnamese friends pretty much prefer the other type, and when I really want to control the grounds, so do I, but when I want quick, well as quick as one can make a drink with a phin, I reach for this. Cleanup is also easier.

title: No more mud
text: These are a must for fans of the perc. They work perfectly, but die-hard percolator users know the key is to run the basket under cool water before inserting the filter, so it clings to the basket before scooping in the ground coffee. If you haven't tried a perc and have memories of grandma's bitter and stale percolated coffee, you owe it to yourself to try it....WITH filters!

title: Actionable bundle of technology
text:
The primary purpose of this AcuRite Indoor Air Quality Monitor is an alert to turn on the humidifier for sensitive family members. It's dimmable and legible. The sampling rate and screen update are appropriate.

Depending on your use, this monitor measures @PM2.5. It's an appropriate indoor green/yellow/red light monitor. @PM2.5 ≤ 12µ = green light. Yellow light between 13-35. >35? Deepening shades of red ... until you can't see color, then like-2000 years in the future, some kid will be digging a hole and strike a void, someone will pour plaster of Paris in the void and you'll live in fame, slain by flaming hot particles just like Pompeii. @PM2.5 the results are comparable to the Air Quality Index (AQI) as locally reported by NOAA.

Relative humidity (RH%) is heuristically linked to PM2.5. The higher the RH%, the lower the PM2.5. The lower the RH%, the higher the PM2.5 reading. I've noticed that an interior RH% ≈ 50% displays 1-5 ppm.

As a note to ‘bunny suit' people, PM2.5 is not the metric for comparisons to ISO cleanroom levels. This monitor might suggest 1-5 ppm, but, my living room is NOT class 10 ... given rugs, etc, it can't be made to get to class 100,000.

Twenty years ago, this sensor was a high-$ industrial proposition and hardly for home use. However, Acurite has packaged a bundle of technology here to deliver excellent value for money.

Was my review helpful? If so, click "Helpful" so I can know. I'm trying hard to increase the value of my reviews to assist in your selection.

text:
This system works really well, but I didn't realize going into it that I would need to purchase their filters to continue using. It's a little complicated but would be great for a social gathering spot where you are making a moderate amount of cold brew daily or weekly.

The flavor of the cold brew I made was absolutely delicious, and the process was easy once I figured it out.

Given that this requires a repurchase in order to continue using, I instead invested in a small mason jar cold brew maker that just makes a couple servings at a time, and have committed to making it more often, rather than making a bigger batch a little less often like with this system.

title: Great solution for storage, wish they came in a cheaper multi pack
text:
This little humidity control jar is basically a wide mouth canning jar with a little plastic basket and a small moisture absorber packet.

It works really well for keeping my seeds from getting overly moist while being stored in the refrigerator, which is how I have been advised to do it – refrigerator and moisture absorbers.

The one quibble I have is that one jar doesn't hold much, and so depending on what the price is when you go to buy, it may not feel cost-effective to purchase all that you need. I would be much happier if the company would offer a small box of 10 of these with 10 moisture absorbers for a modest price, because most of us have wide mouth canning jars sitting around and do not need more of them.

title: Water tastes great!
text: I was using the branded product in my refrigerator water filter, and the water tasted just fine. This one, the water tastes just a notch cleaner and nicer than the other filter when brand-new and fresh. It fit into the fridge just as it should and was easy to install. I do think it is worthwhile to pay a little bit more for the higher end filtration, as I do notice a taste difference.

title: I love this brand of teacup, but the coffee maker isn't my favorite.
text:
I ordered this product hoping that I would get the teacup shown along with the coffee maker, so I was disappointed to receive just the coffee maker. However, this should've been apparent from the price, so that was my own fault.

I was a little disappointed that I can't tell what the mesh strainer is actually made of. Is it made of plastic? Is it actually made of a safe material? I just can't tell. They are saying anywhere what it is actually comprised of.

The claim of dishwasher safe is kind of laughable. It picked up a lot of little food bits in the dishwasher, and I certainly wouldn't have even tried to clean it that way had they not made the claim. It is easy to rinse out under the faucet and there's really no need to dishwasher it.

While I am primarily a tea drinker, I do occasionally have the need to steep coffee, so I tested this on both tea and coffee. For tea, it was extremely effective and would be great for travel when I might not have all of the accoutrements I normally keep with me for steeping the perfect cup of tea.

However, for coffee, it let some of the finer bits through, yet somehow didn't really steep properly. It felt simultaneously watery and muddy. I'm not sure I'd recommend it for coffee, however it was so effective for tea that I do feel it's a good product.

If you are traveling and need a tea or coffee maker that you can use in a pinch, this is a good product which folds down to almost nothing and is easy to clean. However, I wouldn't bother using this at home.

title: A little different from our previous reusable but works great

title: Fit A Samsung Double Door Bottom Freezer Model RF28HFEDTSR.
text:
I wasn't sure this was the correct filter for our fridge but I looked it up online and these ended up working perfectly. I have included the model, serial and compression numbers in the photos in the hope that it will help someone. Just twist and pull the old filter out and then push and twist the new one in. Very Easy! The filter hole is in between the fruit and vegetable drawers.
I read that there are a few ways to get the red filter light to go off after replacing the filter. I held the alarm button for 3-5 secs. You can also hold the water button 3-5 secs.
We have well water and do not drink it due to the taste but the water tasted completely different with this filter and I would absolutely use the water out of the fridge after installing this filter.

side notes:

title: Great for small families, but could be hard to find a place to put it/store it
text:
Some key points about the product
- only uses 5 liters or 1.3 gallons of water per load
- a size comparison is slightly larger than a large countertop oven
- takes 2 hours to do a "normal" wash
- takes regular dishwasher liquid or powder (I do not recommend pods since they are made for use in full sized machines)

What I like about the product
- great size for a small family
- uses less water (5 liters or 1.3 gallons) than it would to handwash the dishes!
- does not need to be hooked up to a water source: fill it with 5 liters of water and a bucket/sink to drain
- we have a full size dishwasher but I don't run it very often and use it more for a drying rack.. we are only a family of 4 and it takes about 2 weeks for us to fill up the dishwasher but there are things I need washed frequently such as toddler sippy cup, coffee cup, etc .. so this is nice to have as a busy mom that has to do a small amount of dishes everyday.
- different settings for your needs: normal wash, wash fruit, etc...
- easy to use
- does not make much noise/pretty quiet

Cons:
- larger/ bulkier than expected
- all of our counters have cabinets above them so it didn't end up fitting anywhere in our kitchen
- had some trouble adding silverware: I had to put knives horizontally in washer because they would just slide right through or were too tall to fit in the washer.
- had a hard time finding somewhere I could put/store it since [like I mentioned before] all my counters have cabinets above them. You need to be able to put it somewhere that is a large surface to place it on, that is also by a 3 pronged outlet, plus be able to drain it somewhere (sink/bucket). I ended up running our first load while it was on top of my clothes dryer but cannot keep it there because it is blocking my laundry cabinet.
- if you don't keep it in a permanent spot you will have to pick it up and move it to use it and it's pretty heavy/bulky to do that.
- drain hose has a mind of its own.. I recommend giving it some time to straighten out and unravel because it kept wanted to go back to the shape it was stored and the suction cup was basically no help with that..

Overall I'd say this is definitely convenient to have it's just a matter of figuring out if you have the correct space for it - and if you do it's a lovely and handy machine to have!

title: perfect for a minimalist or to wash cloth diapers
text: This washer is ideal for an apartment, dorm, an RV, small home, or for a minimalist. The hose attachments make it easy to hook up to a sink/faucet. Some of the key features i really like about it is: it is compact, has built in wheels (making it easier to move), has a clear see-through lid, its energy saving, and has a child lock. I like having a smaller compact washer to wash my cloth diapers in separately (and other soiled clothes/rags) but this is a perfect size for a load of cloth diapers! I do wish that the water hoses it came with were a little longer though, but overall happy and good product.

title: 5 stars
text:
I have been through about 5 of these ice makers. I have used the "Cleaning mode" on them all once a week but it never failed, they would not last. I never realized that I needed a limescale cleaner.

I followed the directions exactly. I added a packet into the water and put it through the cleaning cycle. After the 1st cleaning cycle was over, I ran distilled water (room temp) through it again to make sure that all of the chemicals were out of the machine.

The grinding and loudness of the ice maker was gone and it works like its brand new again!

title: 5 stars

the freezer part actually works well in this little fridge as well. I have had others where it did not. I love the sleek look, it maintains temperature (no exploded drinks like I have had in others as well). This is a great product to be used anywhere you need a refrigerator in a small space.

title: Very close to Original!
text:

In terms of fit and quality it's the exact same as the one available directly from Mr Coffee. The one major difference is the filter color/quality.
